title: 1852–53 United States Senate elections
added: The [[Connecticut legislature]] had failed to elect a senator for the term beginning in 1851.  Democrat [[Isaac Toucey]] was elected in May 1852 to finish the term.

title: 1852–53 United States Senate elections
added: Democratic senator [[William K. Sebastian]] had been appointed May 12, 1848 to continue the term, to which he was elected later that year to finish.
Sebastian was re-elected to a full term in 1853.

title: 1852–53 United States Senate elections
added: Second-term Whig [[John M. Berrien]] resigned May 28, 1852 and Democrat [[Robert M. Charlton]] was appointed May 31, 1852 to finish the term.
Democrat [[Robert Toombs]] was elected in 1852 and would serve through re-election in 1858 and until he withdrew in 1861.

title: 1852–53 United States Senate elections
added: *{{Aye}} '''[[John M. Clayton]]''' (Whig)
* Unopposed<ref name=Delaware/>

title: 1852–53 United States Senate elections
added: One-term Whig [[Joseph R. Underwood]] retired and Know Nothing [[John Burton Thompson]] was elected.

Long-term Whig and former-[[United States Secretary of State|U.S. Secretary of State]] [[Henry Clay]] died June 24, 1852 and Democrat [[David Meriwether (Kentucky)|David Meriwether]] was appointed July 6, 1852 pending a special election, in which he was not a candidate.
Whig [[Archibald Dixon]] was elected September 1, 1852 to finish the term that would end in 1855.
In 1853 the [[Kentucky legislature]] elected Whig former senator [[John J. Crittenden]] to succeed Dixon, far in advance of the 1855 term.

title: 1852–53 United States Senate elections
added: *{{Aye}} '''[[Stephen A. Douglas]]''' (Democratic)75votes
* [[Joseph Gillespie]] (Whig) 19 votes
* [[James H. Collins]] 1 vote<ref name=Illinois/>

title: 1852–53 United States Senate elections
added: First-term Democrat [[James W. Bradbury]] retired and the [[Maine legislature]] failed to elect his replacement until long after the new Congress began.  It wasn't [[1854 United States Senate special election in Maine|until 1854]] that a new senator would be elected.

title: 1852–53 United States Senate elections
added: Free Soil senator [[John P. Hale]] [[1852 United States presidential election|ran for U.S. President]], coming in third place in the popular vote, but failing to win any states.  He lost to the Democratic fellow-New Hampshire senator [[Franklin Pierce]].  He then lost re-election to his senate seat when Democrats took over the [[New Hampshire legislature]] in 1852 state elections.
Democratic former-senator [[Charles G. Atherton]] was returned to the Senate in Hale's place on November 25, 1852.

Atherton died from pulmonary tuberculosis in the first year of his term.
After Republicans retook the [[New Hampshire legislature]] in 1854, Hale was [[1855 United States Senate special election in New Hampshire|re-elected to finish the term]].

title: 1852–53 United States Senate elections
added: Long-time Whig [[Willie Person Mangum|Willie Mangum]] was a candidate for re-election.  Although Democratic former-congressman [[James C. Dobbin]] was a top choice of the [[North Carolina Legislature]], no candidate received a majority of votes in either house, so the seat was left unfilled.<ref>See, e.g., {{Cite web | title= Journals of the Senate and House of Commons of the General Assembly of North-Carolina at its session in 1852 | page=769 | url=https://digital.ncdcr.gov/digital/collection/p249901coll22/id/493877/rec/24 | access-date=November 19, 2020 |website=digital.ncdcr.gov |language=en}}</ref>
The seat would remain vacant until a [[1854 United States Senate special election in North Carolina|1854 special election]].
Dobbin would then be appointed [[United States Secretary of the Navy|U.S. Secretary of the Navy]] and Magnum retired from public service.
